info.title: Authomize API Reference
info.description:
Authomize enables users to integrate your applications with Authomize via custom connectors.

You can use the APIs described in this document to create your connector.

Once data is uploaded and processed successfully, your custom connector will function in the same way as the connectors created by Authomize.

## How does Authomize work?
Authomize works by gathering information about:

· individuals, teams and functions.

· apps, assets and accounts.

· all the relationships between them.

![img.png](https://storagetry1.blob.core.windows.net/public/78d82650-71b0-4909-8444-022aab79add5.png)

## Connector APIs

Authomize connector APIs enable pushing data into Authomize from external sources.

These APIs enable data extracted from outside applications (via application APIs) to be delivered to Authomize.

A connector processes extracted application data to transform it into a format compatible with Authomize.

![img_1.png](https://storagetry1.blob.core.windows.net/public/341bf6ef-2e5b-4284-b715-45105ffbf0f8.png)

## Authentication
To Authenticate use the API Token, with the format: `Authorization: API_Token`.

An API Token is a token you provide when making API calls. 


The API Token should be included in every request to the API in an `Authorization` header.
```
curl -v -X POST \n
     -H "Authorization: {API_Token}" \n
     ...
```

get.description: Download template file for file-provider based on REST API schema

post.description: Insert status message for the given app ID.

delete.description: Clear all status messages for the given app ID

post.description: Set status for the given App ID

parameters.description: Delete all the app data lastly updated before the given date.

parameters.description: Everything from this date and forward.

schema.description: Everything from this date and forward.

patch.description:
Use this endpoint when updating user data.

When editing user data, any combination of fields can be updated at a time.

The uniqueId is requiered and can't be changed.

Only the fields that are supplied will be affected by the PATCH request (others will be unchanged).

parameters.description: Everything from this date and forward.

schema.title: Startdate
schema.description: Everything from this date and forward.

parameters.name: startDate

post.description: A "grouping" is any object that collects multiple accounts or other groupings and can be granted permissions. Examples include groups, roles on certain platforms (e.g. AWS), profiles in certain platforms (e.g. SFDC) and more.

patch.description:
Use this endpoint when updating grouping data.

When editing grouping data, any combination of fields can be updated at a time.

The uniqueId is requiered and can't be changed.

Only the fields that are supplied will be affected by the PATCH request (others will be unchanged).

parameters.description: Everything from this date and forward.

parameters.name: startDate

post.description:
A permission (also referred to as an “entitlement”) is a set of privileges, assigned to a specific target. 
Examples include: file permissions, file shares, GCP entitlements, the actual policies assigning access to roles in AWS, and inline policies.

parameters.description: Everything from this date and forward.

schema.title: Startdate
schema.description: Everything from this date and forward.

parameters.name: startDate

post.description:
Add privileges.

This API enables you to define privileges that can be associated with assets.

For example, Read privileges on a file.

Here you can define the type of privileges and associate it to assets in the Permission API.

patch.description:
Use this endpoint when updating privilege data.

When editing privilege data, any combination of fields can be updated at a time.

The uniqueId is requiered and can't be changed.

Only the fields that are supplied will be affected by the PATCH request (others will be unchanged).

post.description: This API enables you to establish inheritance between privileges, so that a single privilege contains a set of other privileges. For example, an Administrative privilege that contains read and write privileges.

Use this endpoint when updating asset data.

When editing asset data, any combination of fields can be updated at a time.

The uniqueId is requiered and can't be changed.

Only the fields that are supplied will be affected by the PATCH request (others will be unchanged).

post.description:
Use this end point when adding metadata to an identity.
The data of the identity from this API is considered "the source of truth" and overrides the identity data from other systems.

patch.description:
Use this endpoint when updating identity data.

When editing identity data, any combination of fields can be updated at a time.

The uniqueId is requiered and can't be changed.

Only the fields that are supplied will be affected by the PATCH request (others will be unchanged).

post.description: Create new transaction of a connector.

get.description: Retrieve transaction of a connector by {transactionId}.

delete.description: Delete transaction of a connector by {transactionId}.

get.description: Download link to the connector data in archive of csv forms.
Download link to the connector data in archive of csv forms.

schema.title: Response Search V1 Connectors  Connectorid  Export Get

targetId.title: Targetid
targetId.description: Target grouping ID to associate with  **Mandatory**.

targetId.title: Targetid
targetId.description: The ID of the iherited asset (or assets). **Mandatory**

originId.title: Originid
originId.description:
The asset ID in the source system.
As opposed to `uniqueId`, it's not mandatory and can be non-unique

name.title: Name
name.description: The name of the asset. The default is the Asset ID. **Mandatory**

type.description:
The asset types that are supported by Authomize **Mandatory**

Permitted values:

   •	`Application` (federation) 
   •	`Database`
   •	`Drive`
   •	`File`
   •	`Folder`
   •	`Git Repository`
   •	`Integration`
   •	`Project`
   •	`Site`
   •	`Table`
   •	`Ticket`
   •	`Virtual Machine`
   •	`Other`

If the asset type does not exist use `Other`.

originType.title: Origintype
originType.description:
The asset type in the source system.
The default is the canonical type (if not mentioned).

createdAt.title: Createdat
createdAt.description:
The date (in ISO 8601 format) that the asset was created.
The default is `null`.

lastUsedAt.title: Lastusedat
lastUsedAt.description:
The date (in ISO 8601 format) of the last time that the asset was in use.
The default is `null`.

description.title: Description
description.description: A description of the asset (up to 512 characters).

href.title: Href
href.description: A link to the asset in the source system.

tags.title: Tags
tags.description: Tags associated with the asset.

originId.title: Originid
originId.description:
The groupping ID in the source system.
As opposed to `uniqueId`, it's not mandatory and can be non-unique

name.title: Name
name.description: The name of the grouping. The default is the ID field. **Mandatory**

originType.title: Origintype
originType.description: The name of the type of grouping in the source system. The default is `Group`. Example: Group/Alias/AWS Role

type.description:
Allowed values are `Group` and `VirtualGroup`.

The default is `Group`.

`VirtualGroup` are mapped to the Authomize access explorer graph and are not present in other places in the user interface nor are they counted as a group.

isRole.title: Isrole
isRole.description:
If `Role`, the grouping represents a role in the source application and the name of the role is the grouping `name`.

The default is `False`.

anyoneCanJoinOrLeave.title: Anyonecanjoinorleave
anyoneCanJoinOrLeave.description:
Must be either `ture` or `false`.
When set to `true` users can give themselves membership in this grouping without the grouping's managers' or owners' permission. 
Examples include public groups (M365), Google Groups with specific flags, ...
Valid only when `groupingType = Group`

tags.title: Tags
tags.description: Tags on the access grouping.

targetId.title: Targetid
targetId.description: Grouping Target ID  **Mandatory**. The grouping to associate with.

originId.title: Originid
originId.description:
The identity ID in the source system.
As opposed to `uniqueId`, it's not mandatory and can be non-unique

status.description: The user status must be one of the following: `Deleted`, `Disabled`, `Enabled`, `Staged` or `Suspended`.

department.description: The identity's department in the organization.

uniqueId.title: Uniqueid
uniqueId.description:
Privilege ID.

If not defined, set as originName. **Mandatory, must be unique.**

originId.title: Originid
originId.description:
The privilege ID in the source system.
As opposed to `uniqueId`, it's not mandatory and can be non-unique

type.description:
The "canonical" privilege types that are supported by Authomize off-the-shelf: **Mandatory**

Permitted values: 
   •	`Administrative`
   •	`Unknown`
   •	`Read`
   •	`ReadMetadata`
   •	`Write`
   •	`Create`
   •	`Delete`
   •	`Execute`
   •	`Enable`
   •	`Assign`
   •	`Restore`
   •	`Import`
   •	`Export`
   •	`Update`
   •	`Cancel`
   •	`Use`
   •	`Delegate`
   •	`Join`
   •	`Invite`
   •	`Share`

If the privilege type does not exist use `Unknown` or `Use`.

originName.title: Originname
originName.description: The privilege name in the source system.

validateOnly.description: Validate the request without uploading the data into the system.

new_groupings.title: New Groupings
new_groupings.description: A "grouping" is any object that collects multiple accounts or other groupings and can be granted permissions. Examples include groups, roles on certain platforms (e.g. AWS), profiles in certain platforms (e.g. SFDC) and more.

new_permissions.title: New Permissions
new_permissions.description:
A permission (also referred to as an “entitlement”) is a set of privileges, assigned to a specific target. 
Examples include: file permissions, file shares, GCP entitlements, the actual policies assigning access to roles in AWS, and inline policies.

new_privileges.title: New Privileges
new_privileges.description:
Add privileges.

This API enables you to define privileges that can be associated with assets.

For example, Read privileges on a file.

Here you can define the type of privileges and associate it to assets in the Permission API.

new_privileges_grants.title: New Privileges Grants
new_privileges_grants.description: This API enables you to establish inheritance between privileges, so that a single privilege contains a set of other privileges. For example, an Administrative privilege that contains read and write privileges.

new_accounts_association.title: New Accounts Association
new_accounts_association.description: Create association between user accounts and groups.

new_groupings_association.title: New Groupings Association
new_groupings_association.description: Create associations between groups and other groups.

new_assets_inheritance.title: New Assets Inheritance
new_assets_inheritance.description: This API allows you to create a connection between different assets (for example, a folder that contains multiple files).

new_identities.title: New Identities
new_identities.description:
Use this end point when adding metadata to an identity.
The data of the identity from this API is considered "the source of truth" and overrides the identity data from other systems.

StatusMessage.title: StatusMessage
StatusMessage.description:
Model to a connector's status message

Models of this instance will be a part of a list in each connector
document

namespace: Space that defines where did the status come from, like activities, extraction, etc
severity: Status severity
category: Optional; to define what category the status message comes from (Auth error, Creds
    error, etc)
httpStatus: Optional for edge cases, but expected for connectors that rely on HTTP/Graph calls.
    This represents the HTTP error / info status such as 200, 404, 401, etc.
text: User friendly error message
rawMessage: Optional; raw message returned by the connector, if present

StatusRequestSchema.title: StatusRequestSchema
StatusRequestSchema.description:
Model for a connector's status

namespace: Space that defines where did the status come from, like activities, extraction, etc

originId.title: Originid
originId.description:
The user ID in the source system.
As opposed to `uniqueId`, it's not mandatory and can be non-unique

isExternal.title: Isexternal
isExternal.description:
Account is external to Authomize.
Must be either `true` or `false`.

hasMFA.title: Hasmfa
hasMFA.description:
Has Multi-Factor Authentication enabled.
Must be either `true` or `false`.

lastLoginAt.title: Lastloginat
lastLoginAt.description: The last login date in ISO 8601 format.

tags.title: Tags
tags.description: One or more tags on the user account.

uniqueId.title: Uniqueid
uniqueId.description: User's Account ID. **Mandatory, must be unique.**

originId.description:
The user ID in the source system.
As opposed to `uniqueId`, it's not mandatory and can be non-unique

Account is external to Authomize.
Must be either `true` or `false`.

hasMFA.description:

tags.title: Tags
tags.description: One or more tags on the user account.

tags.name: Status
tags.description: The status of the API.

tags.name: Apps
tags.description: Actions at the application level.

tags.name: Accounts
tags.description:
Each account is associated with a specific application.

If the an account already exists on the platform, the account data will be overridden with the new data.

tags.name: Access
tags.description: Access is a way to relate between accounts, roles and assets.

tags.name: Privileges
tags.description: Privileges that allows access to assets.

tags.name: Association
tags.description: Associates between accounts and groups and between groups and other groups.

tags.name: Assets
tags.description:
Each asset is associated with a specific application.

If the an asset already exists on the platform, the asset data will be overridden with the new data.

tags.name: Identities
tags.description:
Use this endpoint when updating identity data.

When editing identity data, any combination of fields can be updated at a time.

The uniqueId is requiered and can't be changed.

Only the fields that are supplied will be affected by the PATCH request (others will be unchanged).
